title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil
author: Berendt, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Clever, creative, crazy, unconventional, and absolutely delightful. Those are some of the words that come to mind after reading Midnight in the GardenClever, creative, crazy, unconventional, and absolutely delightful. Those are some of the words that come to mind after reading Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil by John Berendt. The author, a former New York magazine editor, lived in Savannah on-and-off for eight years, chronicling the comings-and-goings of socialites, politicians, aristocrats, fun-seekers, drag queens, business owners, country lawyers, history buffs, and voodoo devotees. Most prominently, he showcases a murder case that mesmerizes the community and lets many of these actors perform in their natural setting, Savannah, a city that, he concludes, has only one motive: to preserve a way of life that it felt was under siege from all directions. Berendt sums up this way:  The city looked inward, sealed off from the noises and distractions of the world at large. It grew inward too, and in such a way that its people flourished like hothouse plants tended by an indulgent gardener. The ordinary became extraordinary. Eccentrics thrived. Every nuance and quirk of personality achieved greater brilliance in that lush enclosure...."  Berendt put together a remarkable book. It is well worth your time....more

review: I'm not going to write a full  here, but to underscore one point in Cry of the Kalahari. It was fascinating to watch Mark and Delia Owens transfI'm not going to write a full  here, but to underscore one point in Cry of the Kalahari. It was fascinating to watch Mark and Delia Owens transform from naive American college kids looking for a research project to renowned experts/established authors on animal behavior in the Kalahari to advocates for a range of public policies in Africa to protect wildlife. While the Owens' are studying the behavior of animals, we also are witnesses to the behavior of the Owens' as they gain more experience and insight during their six years in the Kalahari. There is much talk in the media and on the web about their behavior after this book was written, and their growing advocacy, but don't let it spoil your enjoyment of an engaging and lovely story. This is a book well worth your time. ...more

title: The Overstory
author: Powers, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Who can argue with a Pulitzer Prize? Or near poetic prose? Or fabulous detail about what trees are and how they interact? Or stories that crisscross gWho can argue with a Pulitzer Prize? Or near poetic prose? Or fabulous detail about what trees are and how they interact? Or stories that crisscross generations and finally intersect in an intense eco-terrorism subplot? From this perspective, Richard Powers’ The Overstory is perfect.But there are other things to consider about the book. Its repetition. Its didactic tone. Its one- sidedness. Its length. Its constant florid descriptions of flora. Its simplistic approach to infinitely complex issues.It certainly is worth reading. In many ways, it is a brilliant book. Powers makes the case that we are connected in multiple ways to trees, all the way down to sharing much common DNA. And that we humans must change our ways to let trees continue the life-sustaining role that they have been playing since humans appeared. But the book's shortcomings keep it from becoming the gem I had expected....more

title: Wild Ride Home: Love, Loss, and a Little White Horse, a Family Memoir
author: Hemp, Christine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Life begins to get a tad wobbly as one approaches middle age. Damages have begun to accumulate. Youthful dreams have begun to darken. But in ChristineLife begins to get a tad wobbly as one approaches middle age. Damages have begun to accumulate. Youthful dreams have begun to darken. But in Christine Hemp’s hands, the challenges and defeats -- and the pain they bring -- do not dim dreams. In fact, they may deepen them, even cast them in more lasting hues. In her book, Wild Ride Home: Love, Loss, and a Little White Horse, a Family Memoir she has captured the texture of life’s middle years. She chronicles the aging and then passing of her parents, her personal battle with breast cancer, and the ups-and-downs of building her own family. And she does so with optimism intact, as if pulled along by the wonder of life itself.She reaches her insights helped, in part, by working with a beautiful, spirited little horse named Buddy. Mistreated in his youth, Buddy misbehaves at times and might even be dangerous. But he can be warm and loving as well. Ms. Hemp interweaves her efforts to understand and reach Buddy with stories of her own life, marked by trials and errors, loss, but also by resolve and perseverance. Ultimately, by accepting Buddy for who he is, warts and all, she grows a special language with him:“My relationship with Buddy has opened a window to a deeper perception of the world. Maybe this is actually what we’re called upon to do in this little life: find home in the most elemental place possible, our own skin.”This is a lovely book. Worth every bit of five stars....more

review: I got to page 244. Brilliant writing goes a long, long way. But, in the end, it doesn’t make up for the thin plot, slow execution, cliched characters,I got to page 244. Brilliant writing goes a long, long way. But, in the end, it doesn’t make up for the thin plot, slow execution, cliched characters, and the unpleasantness, in particular, of the main character. That would be Keith, a low-life cheat, a hustler, self-centered and violent with women, who the author describes over and over again. Sometimes it feels that the only true plot is the dazzling word riffs that loop back around to the ugly traits we already know about this fellow. Keith is a mean, cartoon, bad guy. Then there are other players—Nicola Six who Keith wants to bed and Guy Clinch, a rich guy in love with Nicola. She is working a three-way hustle that, she hopes, will end in Keith murdering her. Now, admittedly, right there you’ve got some plot. Really. Problem is, it drips out so slowly. And the wretchedness of the characters is too much to endure....more

review: This book was delightful, predictable, heartwarming, cliched, funny, beautifully written, and worth every minute. By now, you know the plot: grumpy olThis book was delightful, predictable, heartwarming, cliched, funny, beautifully written, and worth every minute. By now, you know the plot: grumpy old fart, big heart, lost the love of his life, decides to oft himself, but too many wonderful, goofy, loving people give him a new lease on life. Within a few pages, this all becomes pretty clear. And you may wonder, why keep going with this predictable tear jerker?Because the author is brilliant. The main character—rusty, grumpy old Ove—is hilarious in author Fredrick Bakman’s hands. Ove’s view of the world puts poison daggers through the stupid and bureaucratic of everyday life. Bakman could be a stand-up comedian with some of his lines. And his sense of absurdity, humaneness, and connections that we all so long for in this life make this book a wonderful read. ...more

title: Shroud for a Nightingale        (Adam Dalgliesh, #4)
author: James, P.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Two dead nurses, a closeted Nazi, a dour nursing school in a cold winter rain, and Scotland Yard's smartest detective--how can you go wrong? You can'tTwo dead nurses, a closeted Nazi, a dour nursing school in a cold winter rain, and Scotland Yard's smartest detective--how can you go wrong? You can't. P.D. James' The Shroud of the Nightingale had just the feel and delicious danger I like. The first nurse is murdered "live," so to speak, during a teaching demonstration gone horribly wrong--with a hospital quality inspector in the audience, no less. The police come in, ask questions, bumble about and, well, another nurse is suddenly dead. This time it seems to be poison in her daily nightcap. This starts star-detective (and sometime poet) Adam Dalgliesh on a murder investigation centered on a group of young student nurses, several suspicious administrators and hospital officials, and one haughty physician who admits to having an affair with one of the deceased. All of this wrapped into a taught plot, with smart writing. I had a sense I would like the book early-on, when the hospital inspector arrives on the hospital grounds and senses "a sweet fungoid stench of decay." It only gets better from there....more

title: Killing Commendatore
author: Murakami, Haruki
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Just finished reading this impressive book, Killing Commendatore by Haruki Murakami. I will now need about as much time to think about what it's all aJust finished reading this impressive book, Killing Commendatore by Haruki Murakami. I will now need about as much time to think about what it's all about. This shouldn't take more than, oh, two or three months. A small note: One thing I love about Murakami (which drives some people absolutely nuts) is his moment-to-moment narrative of the main character's activities: boiling water for tea, going to the fridge for cold cuts, settling into a thick couch, listening to Strauss' Rosenkavalier, picking out a shirt. Often inconsequential, these moments are nevertheless also often vital to his themes, not the least of which is the importance of each tiny moment of time, the present moment, the quantum world of meaning within each drop--of course, a Buddhist principal contrary to the vast rush of the West forward and to the future.Tim Lott wrote an excellent essay in Aeon in September, 2012, which captures this notion: "The emphasis on the present moment is perhaps Zen’s most distinctive characteristic. In our Western relationship with time, in which we compulsively pick over the past in order to learn lessons from it and then project into a hypothetical future in which those lessons can be applied, the present moment has been compressed to a tiny sliver on the clock face between a vast past and an infinite future. Zen, more than anything else, is about reclaiming and expanding the present moment."That's not to say that Murakami doesn't  the past, especially the damages from World War II, or peer into the future. It's just that so much of his work sends us inward, to the internal beating of our souls, ushered there in part by attention to the nano-moments of time. Now, back to figuring out what Murakami had in mind in Killing Commendatore....more

title: Let the Great World Spin
author: McCann, Colum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let the Great World Spin, Colum McCann's novel of gritty, crowded, sweating New York in the summer of 1974 is an ode to the strong threads, the interwLet the Great World Spin, Colum McCann's novel of gritty, crowded, sweating New York in the summer of 1974 is an ode to the strong threads, the interwoven strands--sometimes nearly invisible--that run through our lives, that tie us together, that link one point with another and then another, and that awaken us sometimes by the sheer audacity of their existence, even in the darkest times. Like the small tightrope walker who, in August 1974, inched his way along the steel thread he'd strung between the Twin Towers, and who brought the city beneath him to a near stop, the people of New York make their way onward, step-by-step, into what lies ahead. Prostitutes, priests, judges, mothers, pedestrians, artists, cops, bartenders, office workers, all balance themselves amid the frequent despair of life, best they can. Along the way, they fail, often. Wars take the sons of mothers. Prostitution and poverty rob the hopes of the young. Car accidents, and snap decisions, and failed marriages, and broken bureaucracies defeat even the most determined, as if life is little but randomness and chaos. And, as readers, we know what is coming--for the Twin Towers, for the people that inhabit them, for the city and the world, in the aftermath of 9/11. But McCann's story, made up of what sometimes feel like unconnected short stories, pulls us forward nonetheless, through the din and the danger. It's strands show us the links in lives, the rebirth and rebuilding, the foundation that, despite frequent destruction, grows stronger--captured brilliantly, in a moment, when a young man on a tightrope performs a death-defying act, against all odds, that makes every little corner of the chaotic world beneath him stop and look and wonder, in awe of the audacity of such hope....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Le Carre's first George Smiley novel, Call for the Dead is a treat for long-time fans of the author and his famous, doughy, unassuming, yet brilliant Le Carre's first George Smiley novel, Call for the Dead is a treat for long-time fans of the author and his famous, doughy, unassuming, yet brilliant spy. Here we have George as he routinely interviews a Foreign Office official who has been fingered (anonymously) as a Soviet spy. All seems well and good--George allows that at that time, in the early 1960s, virtually every intellectual had toyed with Communism as a viable option for the West--so he gives him the all-clear. But the intrigue that follows brings Smiley together with his spy-hunting team (which becomes famous when Le Carre publishes Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy) as they disentangle multiple allegiances and double-dealing in post-WWII/Coldwar Germany. But I hasten to add that this book also works wonderfully as an introduction to Smiley & Company for new Le Carre readers: it starts up a brilliant fictional character that will entertain you for many books to come....more

title: Serena
author: Rash, Ron*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm terribly biased, because my 2014 novel, The Woods, covers ground very similar to Ron Rash's, Serena. Both are set in logging camps, during the GreI'm terribly biased, because my 2014 novel, The Woods, covers ground very similar to Ron Rash's, Serena. Both are set in logging camps, during the Great Depression, featuring timber barons clashing with workers, and a hidden mystery. Though my story takes place in the Pacific Northwest, not North Carolina, and ultimately takes a very different route than Serena, it was hard, as an author, to read past these similarities.That said, I'll try. Serena is a beautifully written novel that mixes mystery, ambition, and survival in a steamy cauldron of Depression-era logging, bureaucratic infighting, and, well, sex. It opens with two of the most amazing sentences I've read in a novel, speaking both of their structure and ability to kick-start a plot. From there, we are introduced to characters that open themselves slowly, so readers discover the nuances and imperfections--and their true intentions--only a bit at a time. There's George Pemberton, who wants to build a powerful timber company in the North Carolina hills; his wife, Serena, whose ambition is every bit as grand as her husband's, and exudes a kind of mystical presence; a pregnant young woman, who works for the timber company and carries Pemberton's unborn child; and various roughnecks, troublemakers, snooty-rich businessmen, and hill people.Rash moves this along nicely, and with evenness, and introduces the true complexity that drives the novel to its conclusion with writing that is as gentle and evocative as the North Carolina forests. But I must also say that the story itself is dark, despite all this beauty. I'm usually up for any kind of mayhem or disharmony in a well-written, well-told story, but this one felt too cold. I had trouble feeling empathy for any of the characters and came to dislike them--well, most of them. Maybe Rash is too good at telling about how mean some people can be.But I'd recommend this book nonetheless. A very enjoyable read. It deserves 4 stars...more

author: Zevin, Gabrielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I gave this book an extra star because I liked the cover. Unfortunately, the book goes downhill rapidly after that. Set on an island off the coast of I gave this book an extra star because I liked the cover. Unfortunately, the book goes downhill rapidly after that. Set on an island off the coast of Hyannis, it is the story of an acerbic bookstore owner whose wife died two years earlier. He's funny, brainy, irreverent as he struggles to keep the store going. He meets an upbeat young woman who represents a book publisher. Along the way is a troubled sister-in-law, an abandoned toddler, a stolen book that is very valuable, and a police chief who hosts a book group that meets at the bookstore. Plenty of material to work with, right? But the author manages to put together a stilted plot packed with so many cliches and wholly unbelievable plot twists that I found myself groaning out loud at times. This destroys any gains the author made in building interesting characters and setting. Which is a shame given the book's potential. This is one of those times when I wonder--given the many glowing s this book has received, including some from prestigious publications--what could they have been thinking?...more

title: Major Pettigrew's Last Stand
author: Simonson, Helen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A very nice read. The book captures a man as the institutions and culture he has built his life upon rapidly approach extinction. As such, Major PettiA very nice read. The book captures a man as the institutions and culture he has built his life upon rapidly approach extinction. As such, Major Pettigrew often appears as a relic, almost a character from a Kipling story, but his deep sense of self and his compassion for others show how he is much more than a man of the past. The Major is able to cut through the cacophony of modern life and communicate with people as they are, whether with a child, an edgy young woman, a devout Muslim, a moody son, or an arrogant land developer. He actually listens and thinks. To be sure, he often stumbles, struggles with his long-held senses of appropriate behavior, and must retrace his steps to correct the mishaps. But he endures and succeeds. The symbols of his rigid connection to the past--the cherished guns, his proper standing at the club, even the often stunting reliance on accepted manners and decorum--slip away as he functions in the noisy modern world. In my view, his last stand is this mighty stand to adapt and grow, and to rely upon compassion and caring in all human endeavors.I did like this book. The author, Helen Simonson, gave us some believable, complex characters. I enjoyed the inner conflict in the Major, as well as his good humor. I also thought she captured the setting beautifully, and kept the plot moving nicely. That said, the book went on much too long. Some characters, especially his son Roger, felt like cliches. And the twists and turns sometimes seemed contrived. I felt that the stabbing and threatened suicide detracted, as if the author wasn't confident enough that her strong storyline of character and aging, love and cultural demands wasn't enough to hold the reader. But in fact, it was plenty strong, at least for this reader. ...more

title: One Summer: America, 1927
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a smart, well-written book about some of the significant events that occurred during the summer of 1927, from Babe Ruth setting the home run rThis is a smart, well-written book about some of the significant events that occurred during the summer of 1927, from Babe Ruth setting the home run record to Charles Lindbergh crossing the Atlantic. Some of these events still echo today, such as the decisions by global bank regulators to lower US interest rates--thus, according to Bryson, setting off the financial chaos that would trigger the 1929 market crash--and the intensity of racial disharmony and outright racism that gripped many parts of the country. Bryson's style is relaxed and informative, often humorous, and he's quick to point out irony. If I have any criticism, it is the same one that I often have for many non-fiction books, that is, the author overdoes the number of facts, statistics, and details. Yes, that's what these books are all about, but they can sometimes miss the more profound points because of the excessive details. On the whole, Bryson does a good job with this. Strongly recommended.One Summer: America, 1927...more

title: Wolf Hall        (Thomas Cromwell, #1)
author: Mantel, Hilary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Call it Tom and Jane and Henry and Anne and Mary and Richard and, well, more Toms and Marys. They all want to kill or screw or marry or divorce or schCall it Tom and Jane and Henry and Anne and Mary and Richard and, well, more Toms and Marys. They all want to kill or screw or marry or divorce or scheme or plot against one another. Hillary Mantel takes on the Herculian task of settling down this oft told tale of Henry VIII, and certainly presents much of it beautifully. But it is overly long, confuses the reader, and makes too little effort to help the reader keep all the players strait. Could have been great at half the length and if she hadn't used "he" to describe Cromwell's thoughts and actions in the very same context that she was also referring to other male characters. So, often, the reader must ask, "who the hell does 'he' refer to?" That said, she presents Cromwell in a fairly positive light, which I hadn't seen before, and effectively captures the subtle changes that come about in his character as he tries to steer a sex and power hungry king, a most inconvenient divorce, complicated relations with a changing shape of European powers, and of course the break with Rome....more

title: The Sea
author: Banville, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is the beauty of this book -- the watercolor writing that gives the slanted sunlight and cresting waves nuance and, often, intent; the presentatThere is the beauty of this book -- the watercolor writing that gives the slanted sunlight and cresting waves nuance and, often, intent; the presentation of the purity of youth, delighting in the salty softness of summertime sands and discovering the arresting humidity of puberty and sensuality; and the meandering reminiscences of the main character, Max Morden, who has come back to the seaside resort of his youth to understand who he is and, after the death of his wife, where he belongs. But then there is its brutality -- death and decay and depression and drunkenness; Max Morden's anger and repulsion at the gritty realities of life, from his wife's death to the realization that the physical of act of sex is sweaty and smelly and so far removed from that single moment of "instant divinity" when one finally touches a breast or touches the lips of a pretty girl. Then, of course, there is Max's constant, nearly instinct-driven journey toward his own death and destruction, rejecting all manner of love and acceptance along the way.The Sea, by John Banville, was the Man Booker prize winner in 2005. Understanably, it garnered massive praise. But it is a complex, often deadly cold tale that requires a detachment in the reader to fully appreciate the work and to step back to gather in its breadth. It also takes some patience, because Banville's brilliant writing is almost undone by his sophomoric use of names and symbols to underscore his meaning. To wit, the word "morden" in German means to kill or to end life, which is Max's apparent life-goal, at least as far as his own life is concerned. Giving the character the name "max" makes it only worse. The visiting family in the seaside resort are the Grace family -- the source of Max's fascination with daughter Chloe, her mother, and even the governess, Rose. Max indeeds finds grace in the lips and scent of Chloe, and in the upskirt views that her mother offers Max. And then there is the color blue which the author hits us repeatedly over the head with, blue as in sea, light, air, breath, etcBut that aside, Bannville offers a look into a character type that lives for that perfect moment of glee -- discovery, awareness, delight -- but then shuffles off into hiding when it realizes that extending the moment requires hard work, defeat, assertiveness, and, well, living. Max falls in schoolboy love with Chloe's mother, and reaches near ecstasy when she gives him a look at her private regions, but then feels instantly used, even taken advantage of. Same with Chloe, a nymph of the sea who he dislikes and bashes mere moments after he kisses her lips and declares his love for her.Bu the again, he is that type of man. He aches for his own demise. He will not accept his dying wife's admonitions to just go out and live. He is eternally caught in a threesome, whether with the Graces, or Chloe and her twin, or even with his landlady and the aging fellow boarder. But stepping out of that role would nearly sicken him -- he is more a leech, a sucker (and harsh judger of life) than an active participant. Deep in his soul, at least as a youngster, he sought consummation, but found that consummation was complicated. In reading this book I wonder if Bannville is aiming at male egos, always eager for the hunt and the capture, but bored with the aftermath. Max is surrounded by big, powerful women, many of whom seem to know themselves (and can see through him). And he realizes very late that two of his apparent male "conquests" -- one with Mrs. grace and one with the aging landlady-- were simply elements of lesbian love that he just downright misinterpreted.Three stars is the best I can do,...more

title: The Last Kind Words Saloon
author: McMurtry, Larry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Maybe this is Larry McMurtry's little joke on readers, ers, and the big-talk New York City publishing crowd. After all, he's pulled together driMaybe this is Larry McMurtry's little joke on readers, ers, and the big-talk New York City publishing crowd. After all, he's pulled together dribs and drabs of cowboys-and-Indians stories, riffs of conversation between Wyatt Earp and Doc Holliday, near random scenes of the soon-to-disappear Wild West, and tossed them together into a physically very thin novel that seems half written, disjointed, and haphazard much of the time. As many of the one- star s suggest, is this just a blown-off after-thought of a famous writer bored with the franchise, but still mining the gold that it pours out?Not at all. This is Lonesome Dove Lean: a tale of an ending in American history, without the beautiful detail, without the hues and colors of the original. This book is stark, sometimes primitive. It strips the ending of the West to its barest bones. It mixes scenes that crisscross the imaginary boundary of the dying Wild West andthe uncertain, modern future, almost as disconnected news reports -- an Indian ambush, an English investor, violent deaths on the plains, Buffalo Bill's Wild West show, the shoot-out at the OK Corral, and the new California which becomes home to the Wild West odds-and-ends just as it becomes the birthplace of the lasting American legend. Wyatt Earp and Doc Holliday ruminate and jawbone their way back and forth across this great divide, sometimes cowboyin' and sometimes shooting and sometimes just play-acting as the world moves on around them, and increasingly without them.As McMurtry says, he has written his characters as"afloat in time," to show the legends not in actual detailed history, but in their proper place in the big,broad sweep of America's history....more

title: The Director
author: Ignatius, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A nicely paced spy yarn that finds the new director of the CIA up to his ears in potential double-agents, geeky-hip underworld hackers, and an echo-chA nicely paced spy yarn that finds the new director of the CIA up to his ears in potential double-agents, geeky-hip underworld hackers, and an echo-chamber bureaucracy that eats what it kills. Good-looking billionaire Graham Weber accepts the job to clean up the mess, but finds that his private sector gut instincts may get him more into trouble than solve problems. Readers get to enjoy a snappy ride through international spy networks, high-tech cyber snooping, and old-school pressure politics as Weber sorts through allies, suspects, and a world of self-doubt. Author David Ignatius gives us top-notch plot and an array of complex characters that defy stereotype, except, unfortunately, Weber himself. And, in places, the writing becomes slightly cliched. But this one is a keeper....more

title: Possession
author: Byatt, A.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a joy to read on so many levels -- mystery, poetry, fairies, character studies, transformation, and, to quote a line from the Rolling StoThis book is a joy to read on so many levels -- mystery, poetry, fairies, character studies, transformation, and, to quote a line from the Rolling Stones: "...sex and sex and sex." Byatt's mastery of the language and prose is apparent on every page, from the poetry-like prose of the early pages to the rapid-fire delivery during the detective-game ending. Some criticisms are valid: a tad too much poetry detracts, particularly opening every chapter (often having concluded the previous chapter); and symbolism (green, white, apples) that pounds the reader -- or at least treats the reader a bit too much like a college freshman. But these are quibbles. Overall, a brilliant book....more

title: Interpreter of Maladies
author: Lahiri, Jhumpa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At times, it is hard to believe that this book won the Pulitizer Prize for fiction. A collection of short stories by Jhumpa Lahiri, it presents characAt times, it is hard to believe that this book won the Pulitizer Prize for fiction. A collection of short stories by Jhumpa Lahiri, it presents characters, usually of Indian descent, who struggle with life's challenges large and small -- a failing marriage, a housewarming party, a tour of an ancient temple, a hoped-for promotion. Across many of these stories runs a complex, many-hued backdrop: the characters are somewhere along the transition from India to America. Some are born in India but move to America; others are born in America but interact with families still in India.This is a rich environment for producing high-end, nuanced fiction. But it doesn't seem that way at the beginning. In fact, the early stories, on their own, feel thin: a struggling marriage that falls apart a little too predictably over a stillborn child; an American couple of Indian descent who return to India to visit, but who drip of reckless, high-cost, over-sexualized American culture. They seem to have lost their religion, their depth, their way in their transition from "Indian" to "American." In one of the early stories, an American schoolgirl, whose parents are from India and living in the US, wants to learn more about the battle between Pakistan and India, a war that is raging at that time. But when she wanders to the back of the library in her US school to find books on the subject, her American teacher chastises her because the books bear no relevance to the book report she is supposed to be focused on.These, and other examples like them, made me feel initially that this collection was simply not very sophisticated; not a book of Pulitzer Prize dimensions. But the Awards Committee of the Pulitzer Prize kept reading, as did I. And they apparently discovered what I did -- that this rich environment of complexity and nuance, of India and America, old and new, modern and ancient begins to yield stories of depth, of deep and confusing questions, and of subtlety in meanings that stay with the reader well beyond the completion of the read. Indeed, Lahiri is writing at the top levels of current fiction, despite the occassional clangs of symbolism or predictiability... (More to come)...more

title: American Pastoral
author: Roth, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is no American Pastoral. There is only American berserk, according to Roth. Bad things happen, very bad things -- explosions, rapes, cheating spThere is no American Pastoral. There is only American berserk, according to Roth. Bad things happen, very bad things -- explosions, rapes, cheating spouses, nasty children, prostate cancer, forks aimed at the eye. This is true even for the handsome, seemingly perfect, excessively talented high school athletic star and his beauty-pageant wife.My reading of this book is that it is a very personal statement about what life brings. There is the perfection we can often see in youth, but that perfection is an illusion. Don't try to embrace it and hold it. Because there is another wholly unexpected event coming along that will disrupt it and, very likely, blow it to the sky. I suppose this is a very cynical view of life, but as spoken in the voice of an aging novelist and focused on the life of a high-school hero whose best attempts often end in failure or total loss, it feels -- as I noted -- like a very personal, lonely lament of a life shaped by harsh realities and disappointments. More of a "coming-to-terms with what I've seen" than "this is a lousy life and don't expect to be happy." Others may see this point differently.This book is beautifully written but also terribly overwritten. I felt bludgeoned by paragraph after paragraph that said the same thing -- again, in gorgeous prose. That said, this is a book that is worth the time. Philip Roth is an American treasure, even when the message he conveys is melancholy....more

review: A remarkable book that reads like an epic poem. Beautifully written, yet extraordinarily difficult to read, which seems like a total contradiction. BuA remarkable book that reads like an epic poem. Beautifully written, yet extraordinarily difficult to read, which seems like a total contradiction. But Morrison's style is often indirect, dances back and forth in time, and often captures thoughts and words more as electronic flashes from the brains of it characters than as organized memories or linear narrative. Yet the journey is well worth taking....more

review: One of the things I love about le Carre' is the sense of characters lost in a bureaucratic labyrinth, and the reader is just as confused as they are, One of the things I love about le Carre' is the sense of characters lost in a bureaucratic labyrinth, and the reader is just as confused as they are, at least for awhile. The downside of this theme is that all can seem hopeless and doomed. In A Delicate Truth, le Carre' gives us a feel for the human in the labyrinth--the person, with a family, a wife, a retirement. It's a more personal, thus perhaps even more real for us. An excellent read by one of the masters....more
